Diagnosis
	1. Inflammatory breast cancer right breast, T4dN3M1
	Date of diagnosis
	March 2024

	Treatment aim
	Palliative

	Summary of completed treatment and relevant dates

	Surgery
	Not indicated due to inflammatory component and metastatic disease

	Chemotherapy
	15 March 2024 - 12 April 2024: Weekly Paclitaxel with Atezolizumab

	Clinical studies
	None

	Current disease status
	Progressive disease with deteriorating clinical status

	Current issues
	Worsening liver function, increasing dyspnoea, deteriorating performance status

	Summary of consultation
	This 42-year-old lady's case was discussed at today's Breast MDT following concerning clinical deterioration over the past 2 weeks. She initially presented with inflammatory breast cancer in March 2024, with widespread liver metastases. Initial treatment with weekly Paclitaxel and Atezolizumab was commenced based on high PDL1 expression (TILs 70%). Unfortunately, after 4 cycles, she has experienced clinical deterioration with worsening liver function (bilirubin rising from 24 to 89), new onset ascites requiring drainage, and increasing breathlessness at rest.

The most recent CT performed on 15/4/24 shows progressive disease with increasing size and number of liver metastases, new pleural effusions, and enlarging axillary lymphadenopathy. Her performance status has declined from ECOG 1 to ECOG 3.

The MDT recommendations, after careful review of all available options, are:
1. Discontinue current treatment due to clear disease progression
2. Switch to oral Capecitabine at reduced dose (75%) with careful monitoring of liver function
3. Early palliative care involvement
4. Consider pleural drainage if symptoms worsen

	Further investigations
	Weekly liver function monitoring
Repeat CT in 6 weeks if tolerating new treatment

	Medication prescribed
	Capecitabine 75% dose to commence
Dexamethasone 8mg daily for 5 days then reduce

	Follow up
	Urgent oncology review in one week
Palliative care review arranged for tomorrow

	Required GP actions
	Please monitor liver function weekly
Please support palliative care referral

	Summary of information given to the patient
	Discussion held with patient and family regarding poor response to initial treatment and need to change approach. They understand the palliative nature of ongoing care.
